14 Ex. <s>22<\s> It was found by trials, that the releative position of 
two sets of fringes when formed by three slips only of glass 
plates, connected together as in Experiment 12<s>20<\s>, could not be 
changed at pleasure; but, by using four slips, and having a set 
of fringes formed between each pair, which were unconnected, 
these could be placed the one over the other in any position 
& at any required angle; by this arrangement it was 
discovered, that whatever was the magnitude of the angle 
formed by the two sets of primaries, that angle was 
always bisected by the central band of the intersectionaries. 
& altho these latter evidently proceed from the crossings of 
the two sets of primaries, yet they are never continued thro-
ugh those crossings to the opposite angle at A. fig <s>8<\s>6 
nor could they be made to appear in any angle formed 
by primary fringes, unless the said fringes were so dis-
posed as to have their red sides turned inwards, or towards each 
other. this remarkable fact was proved by several repe-
titions of the same experiment. 
15 Ex. <s>28<\s>. In the course of making these experiments I had 
accidentally left a single slip of glass on one of the pairs bet-
ween which a set of primaries were formed, without any 
other pressure than its own weight; on examining the ap-
paratus a few minutes afterwards, I was agreeably surprized 
to find no less than four setts of the same kind of fringes 
which appeared in the angle between the two setts of prim-
aries as before related in Experiment 12<s>20<\s>, almost parallel 
to each other, & nearly so to the primaries, & at about an inch 
distant in front therof.  (see fig. 5<s>7<\s>) the set marked 2 had broader 
fringes, more vivid in colour, & consisted of a greater number 
(from 15 to 19) than those setts on each side therof; for these 
latter appeared to have that inferiority of colour to the principal 
set, that it bore to the primary set. all the four sets were 
by attentive observation visible to the naked eye, & were all 
divided into two classes by a central band as was before observed 
of the others; & on application of the shadow, were found to 
consist of primary & transmitted fringes precisely in the same 
manner as first primaries or Newtonian rings.
